Award.AwardTitle: Synergistic Effects of Climate-Related Variables on Larval Sea Urchins: Performance to Gene Expression
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gretchen E.Hofmann
IOS-1010536
Title: Synergistic effects of climateÂ­related variables on larval sea urchins: Performance to gene expression

Oceans and the creatures living in them face significant challenges in the future as a result of global climate change. Together, ocean warming and ocean acidification (an increase in ocean pH due to the absorption of atmospheric carbon dioxide) present a "double jeopardy" situation for marine organisms, challenging many aspects of their biology from reproduction to growth and perhaps even survival. Since the conditions in the oceans will change rapidly (leaving little time for adaptation), it is a critical priority to study the tolerances of today's marine organisms, because they and their offspring will be the ones facing the consequences of climate change in their marine habitat.

The goal of this project is to study an early developmental stage of the purple sea urchin (Strongylocentrotus purpuratus) and investigate how the larvae, at swimming and feeding stage, will respond to the simultaneous change in temperature and pH (ocean acidification). After larvae are raised in the laboratory in seawater conditions that mimic the projected pH and temperature of future oceans, the investigators will measure oxygen consumption, characteristics of their metabolism such as fat content, and examine how their genes are activated in response to the stress of higher temperatures and more acidic pH conditions. The outcomes of this research projects and resources for teachers and students in classrooms will be made available through http://hofmannlab.msi.ucsb.edu/.

Although sea urchins may not be as familiar to the general public as salmon or oysters, they are an ecologically and economically important species on the West Coast of the United States. For example, the sea urchins on the California coast support an important wild fishery; in 2008, the catch from sea urchin diving had a value of ~$10 million in California alone. As grazing herbivores, sea urchins are important to healthy coastal marine ecosystems. The sea urchin is a excellent study system, allowing the use of modern research tools to illuminate the implications of climate change for important human concerns such as food sources, fisheries that provide food and jobs, and healthy marine ecosystems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to increasing levels of anthropogenic carbon dioxide (CO2), ocean acidity and ocean warming are predicted to change dramatically by the end of the 21st century. Specifically, increased dissolved CO2 concentrations in the global ocean are predicted to reduce the pH of surface ocean waters from 8.1 now to ~7.8 by the year 2100. Additionally, the average surface seawater temperatures are predicted to increase by anywhere from +1ºC to +6ºC by the year 2100. The biological consequences of these complex and interacting factors are important to understand in terms of predicting how key marine ecosystems will respond to environmental change. The central goal of this proposal is to examine how a key marine invertebrate, the purple sea urchin, will respond to these changes.

From a global change biology perspective, organisms generally have three responses to environmental change: (1) migration (i.e., range shifts), (2) using existing physiological plasticity to tolerate conditions, and (3) adaptation (true microeveolution). Since conditions in the marine environment are expected to change rapidly – within decades in some parts of the ocean – it is key to begin to understand the resilience and tolerance that exists within contemporary populations of marine organisms. Chances are that these organisms will experience alterations in their environment in the near future. However, it is also important to note that we must also consider what organisms experience in the environment, and how their evolutionary history might determine their response to interacting stressors in an environmental change context. For example, although corals are thought to be ‘canaries in the coal mine’ in terms of negative responses to ocean acidification (OA), recent data suggests that the variation in pH on a daily basis on coral reefs is dramatic – ranging from 7.6 to 8.4. Thus, understanding how OA stress and temperature stress combine in the future will interface with tolerances of today’s genotypes and phenotypes is a vital step to understanding impacts on future marine populations. And further, laboratory experiments need to be framed using what we know about the natural exposures of our studying organisms and their physiological responses to these interacting factors.

Using a combination of lab and field experiments, the project had two main take away messages. First, we found that simultaneous exposure to increased temperature and pCO2 significantly reduced the metabolism of sea urchin embryos, and triggered a widespread down-regulation of many genes. We also found that the driver of ocean pH change, pCO2 levels, but not temperature impaired calcification, the process used to make the larval skeleton. Collectively, our results indicate that ocean environmental change variables will interact to exceed thresholds for optimized physiological performance in this key marine species. A second finding showed that purple urchins have abundant genetic variation for traits that are changed in response to low pH/high pCO2 conditions, substantially altering projections of performance of this species in the future oceans. We also found that there are subtle differences between our study sites on the US west coast, in this case different populations, in the effects of high pCO2, providing the first-ever evidence of local adaptation to pH in any marine invertebrate.

Overall the results of the project provided critical insight into how and whether marine populations could adapt to future environmental change in the coastal ocean of the US west coast. Importantly the project also supported the training of several early career scientists – graduate students and postdoctoral scholars – at UC Santa Barbara.
